titleStmt.title: A parallel image encryption method based on compressive sensing

affiliation.orgName: Graduate School of Information Science and Electrical Engineering
Department of IT Convergence and Application Engineering

analytic.title: A parallel image encryption method based on compressive sensing

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Recently, compressive sensing-based encryption methods which combine sampling, compression and encryption together have been proposed. However, since the quantized measurement data obtained from linear dimension reduction projection directly serve as the encrypted image, the existing compressive sensing-based encryption methods fail to resist against the chosen-plaintext attack. To enhance the security, a block cipher structure consisting of scrambling, mixing, S-box and chaotic lattice XOR is designed to further encrypt the quantized measurement data. In particular, the proposed method works efficiently in the parallel computing environment. Moreover, a communication unit exchanges data among the multiple processors without collision. This collision-free property is equivalent to optimal diffusion. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed encryption method not only achieves the remarkable confusion, diffusion and sensitivity but also outperforms the existing parallel image encryption methods with respect to the compressibility and the encryption speed.

div.head: Background
div.p: Nowadays, multimedia data have been widely spread through the Internet. Since the private data are particularly vulnerable to eavesdropping during the data transmission, the confidentiality is required for such applications as Internet conference, Internet security camera, live TV, video-on-demand and telemedicine. Various encryption standards like DES, AES, RSA and IDEA [21,27] have been developed and widely used as a protection against illegal access to the private textual information. However, conventional text encryption method is not directly appropriate for multimedia data due to the following three reasons [14,29]. First, the image size is always larger than that of text. Thus, the time consumption of image encryption and decryption greatly increase according to the image size. Second, the contour of original image still appears in its encrypted image because the conventional cryptography methods [14] fail to eliminate the considerable amount of perceptual redundancy. For example, the resulting image which is directly encrypted by AES (ECB mode) is shown in Fig. 1(b). As can be observed, the corresponding encrypted image is still intelligible to some extent [13,25]. Third, an exact decryption of textual data is required while that is not always necessary for image decryption. In many applications, a decrypted image preserving its original semantic information is acceptable. In addition, due to the large amounts of multimedia data, it is usually desired to implement compression prior to transmission especially under the circumstance of limited storage resource or transmission bandwidth.

Compressive Sensing (CS) [2,6,7] is a newly emerged sampling-reconstruction technique which reduces the sampling rate at the expense of a complex reconstruction on the recipient. To sum up, the essence of CS is to randomly downsample the original data, and to search the optimal solution of an underdetermined linear system for reconstruction. A more detail introduction of CS is given in section 2. CS-based magnetic resonance imaging is a representative application with the potential for significant scan time reductions [18]. In this paper, we propose a parallel image encryption method which is well geared towards the CS circumstance. Our proposal fulfills optimal diffusion owing to dimension adjustability of the CS framework. It is worthwhile to mention that the proposed method caters to the requirement of compression prior to transmission by encrypting an image in its dimension reduction space. In this sub-section, we survey existing works related to CS-based encryption and parallel image encryption methods. Comparative studies are conducted in the performance evaluation section taking these related methods as competitors.

The compression-combined encryption methods based on CS were proposed in [11,16,23,24]. Sampling and compression were combined together through a linear dimension reduction measurement process. Moreover, the randomness of measurement matrix rendered the measurement data unintelligible. This implied that encryption was also completed as a by-product.

Rachlin and Baron [24] demonstrated that, from the perspective of ciphertext-only attack, although the CS-based encryption method could not achieve the perfect security, cracking the secret key required prohibitive time complexity. Orsdemir et al. [23] proposed a notion named as robust encryption. As the terminology suggests, the encrypted image was tolerant of noise contamination. The security analysis covered the resistance against the brute force and structured attacks. They claimed that the computational intractability made attacks infeasible in practice. Facing the unavoidable problem of packet loss during wireless transmission, Liu, Gao and et al. [11,16] quantified the anti-packet loss ability of the CS-based encryption method. Although all above CS-based methods [11,16,23,24] can provide encrypted images without leaking any visual contour, the absence of the diffusion mechanism leaves a door widely open for the chosen-plaintext attack. This loophole is analyzed in the section 3.

Parallel image encryption had also spurred a great deal of research activities due to the promising high speed encryption. Mirzaei et al. [20] proposed a parallel image encryption method. Image segmentation stage produced four sub-images, and then exchanged their positions. Pixel permutation was governed by a total shuffling matrix while parallel gray value substitution depended on the joint states of two chaotic systems. However, their method lacked of the diffusion mechanism, and thus the security was vulnerable in terms of the chosen-plaintext attack. Zhou et al. [31] invented a parallel image encryption structure involving a well designed communication unit which exchanged data among multiple processors. Their method solved the intrinsic contradiction between parallelism and diffusivity. The experimental results exhibited that the full diffusion could be achieved after three rounds of encryption. Liao et al. [15] imitated the self-adaptive encryption [10] and proposed a parallel method based on the property that waveform of a sine wave was sensitive to its three parameters: amplitude, wavelength and distance. Their encryption method could achieve the full diffusion profiting from a similar communication unit. As usual cases, at least three rounds of encryption were essential. 1

div.head: Challenging issues
div.p: We summarize three challenge issues and list them as follows.

(1) The CS-based encryption methods [11,16,23,24] merely survive against the ciphertextonly attack due to the absence of a diffusion process. The first challenging issue is how to enhance the security for resisting against the chosen-plaintext attack.
(2) The necessary round of encryption is usually regarded as a significant performance criterion since repeated iteration operations undermine the computational efficiency.

The second challenging issue is how to decrease the necessary round2 while retaining full confusion and diffusion performance. (3) An additional requirement, namely computation and communication load balance among multiple processors, arises from the parallel structure. Specifically, if and only if each processor is allocated by balance unit throughput,3 the whole system can work concertedly, otherwise processors with lightweight unit throughput have to wait for the ones allocated by heavy unit throughput. The third challenging issue is how to balance the workload so that all processors share a fair unit throughput.

div.head: Our contribution
div.p: In this paper, we aim at the loophole of previous works [11,16,23,24], and propose a parallel encryption method well geared towards the compressive sampling. We highlight contributions and list them as follows.

(1) For security enhancement, the proposed encryption method works under a two-stage mode. The first stage, akin to the previous works [11,16,23,24], compressively samples an image in parallel. In the second stage, the diffusion process is introduced by iteratively implementing permutation, substitution, block-wise exclusive-or (XOR) operation and communication. Our proposal enhances the security in terms of resisting against the chosen-plaintext attack. (2) The proposed communication unit yields the collision-free data exchange which is equivalent to optimal diffusion. Benefiting from the dimension adjustability mechanism, our proposal can achieve the optimal diffusion independent of the aspect ratio of original image. (3) To avoid discussing the optimal scheduling problem, we assume that each processor has the same processing capacity. On the basis of this assumption, the unit throughput of each processing is balanced as long as multiple processors share equal workload. As discussed later, the balanced workload allocation problem becomes equivalent to the achievement of collision-free data exchange. Therefore, the additional requirement given in challenging issues (3) is no longer intractable, and can be satisfied independent of the aspect ratio.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the compressive sensing in brief. Section 3 analyzes the loophole of previous works [11,16,23,24] in terms of the chosen-plaintext attack. Section 4 will be devoted to elaborating the proposed encryption method. In Section 5, the quantitative experiment results are exhibited, and we draw the conclusion in Section 6.

div.head: Compressive sensing overview
div.p: Compressive sensing, also known as compressive sampling [6,7], can sample a sparse or compressible signal below the Nyquist rate. CS has been generally recognized as a high speed signal acquisition technique. The prerequisite for a successive reconstruction is that the original signal should be sparse. Intuitively, most natural images are not simple in the spatial domain. Fortunately, the sparse representation of an image can be derived from various decomposition algorithms such as Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT), Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) or overcomplete basis transform [22].

Suppose that x is a signal with length N. We deal with image data by first vectorizing it into one-dimension vector. For simplicity, assume that {ψ i }(i=1,⋯,N) is a normal orthonormal basis in ℝ N . Basis matrix with the ψ i as columns is denoted by Ψ. The decomposition coefficient s is the equivalent representation of x in Ψ domain. If only K entries of s are non-zero, where K≪N, x is termed as K-sparse signal. The linear measurement process can be expressed as:
div.formula: y ¼ Φx ¼ ΦΨs ¼ Θsð1Þ
div.p: where Φ is the M×N measurement matrix, and y stands for the measurement data with length M (M<N). The sensor matrix Θ is the product of Φ and Ψ.

Equation (1) describes M×N inner products between x and M rows of Φ. The asymmetric size of measurement matrix results in an ill-posed problem with respect to the reconstruction, which means Eq. ( 1) has infinitely many solutions. To simplify this problem, a necessary and sufficient condition has been proposed in [5], namely Restricted Isometry Property (RIP), which can be cast as follow:
div.formula: 1 À " K ð Þ s k k 2 Θs k k 2 1 þ " K ð Þ s k k 2
div.p: We loosely say that a matrix Θ obeys the RIP of order K if ε K is not too close to one. If the RIP holds, a steady solution can be obtained from the above underdetermined system. A more intuitive equivalent condition requires that the measurement matrix Φ must be incoherent with the basis matrix Ψ. Specifically, it means that the rows {ϕ i } of Φ cannot sparsely represent the columns {ψ j } of Ψ (and vice versa) [2]. The above condition can be satisfied with overwhelming probability, when elements of measurement matrix Φ are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) random variables taking on their values from a Gaussian probability density function with mean zero and variance 1/N [7]. Meanwhile, as another prerequisite for successful reconstruction, the measurement data length M is restricted by the inequality below:
div.formula: M ! cK log N K = ð Þð2Þ
div.p: where c is a small constant. The length M in inequality (2) is a crucial factor related to the compression rate. Another factor is the quantization level for measurement data. On the observation of the Eq. ( 1), we conclude that dimension reduction projection compresses the data, and cipher property owes to the randomness of measurement matrix. The reconstruction boils down to a convex optimization process:
div.formula: b s ¼ argmin s 0 k k 1 subject to s 0 ¼ Θy
div.p: In this paper, Orthogonal Matching Pursuit (OMP) is adopted to reconstruct the original signal from the measurement data y. OMP is a reliable and efficient greedy algorithm whose computational complexity is O(KlnN) [26].

div.head: Security analysis on CS-based encryption method
div.p: In the previous methods [11,16,23,24], the security analysis only concerns the computational complexity of brute force attack. However, that is not adequate if opponents have obtained temporary access to the encryption machinery. In this section, we reveal their security loophole from the perspective of chosen-plaintext attack, in the sense that N plain-cipher pairs are sufficient to break them, where N is the length of plaintext.

In secret key cryptography, the unintelligible measurement data are transmitted over the public channel while the key used for generating random measurement matrix is assigned to the intended receivers through the secure channel. We bypass by guessing the key instead of directly exposing the random measurement matrix.

Suppose that the basis matrix Ψ equals an identity matrix I. It is worthwhile to mention that this assumption is impartial since the general sparse transform Ψ is public to all users. As an expansion form of Eq. ( 1), the measurement data y can be represented linearly by columns ϕ i :
div.formula: y ¼ x 1 f 1 þ x 2 f 2 þ; Á Á Á ; þx N f N
div.p: where x i stands for i th element of vector x. Likewise, the i th column of Φ is denoted by ϕ i .
Define a sparse vector x [k] taking following form:
div.formula: x ½k ¼ x i ¼ 0 i 6 ¼ k x i ¼ 1 i ¼ k & i ¼ 1; Á Á Á ; N
div.p: where each sparse vector contains only one non-zero entry. We collect a complete plaintext set
div.formula: X ¼ x k ½ k ¼ 1; Á Á Á; N j È É consisting of N sparse vectors.
div.p: Plaintext in set X is multiplied by random measurement matrix Φ one by one. According to Eq. ( 1) and the assumption Ψ= I, N outputs become y ½k ¼ Φx ½k ¼ f k , where k=1, …, N. In this case, the ciphertext set Y ¼ fy ½k jy ½k ¼ Φx ½k ; k ¼ 1; Á Á Á ; N g is equivalent to the random measurement matrix taking the form Φ ¼ ½f 1 jf 2 j Á Á Á jf N ¼ ½y ½1 jy ½2 j Á Á Á jy ½N . Therefore, an attacker can expose the random measurement matrix as long as he/she sequentially traverses and encrypts all N plaintext vectors in the set X.
Our proposed encryption method can not only work in parallel but also resist against the chosen-plaintext attack through introducing the diffusion mechanism.

div.head: Overview
div.p: Since image data after one-dimension vectorizing brings on an enormous measurement matrix, to alleviate this problem, Gan [9] proposes the block compressive sensing which is memory efficient and enables parallel sampling. Image acquisition is performed in a block-by-block manner through a block measurement matrix Φ B . The complete block diagonal measurement matrix takes the following form: As mentioned before, the proposed method is composed of two stages. The first stage carries out the image acquisition akin to the previous works [11,16,23,24]. We slightly deviate from their way with respect to block-wise and parallel sampling. In the second stage, the well designed block cipher aims at inheriting the parallelism and introducing the diffusion process to resist against the chosen-plaintext attack. Both two stages gear together and work in harmony. The encryption configuration flowchart is illustrated in Fig. 2. We emphasize that block compressive sensing plays a role of signal sampling or image acquisition. Digital operations beginning from the second stage are directly applied on the quantized measurement data in their dimension reduction space. Thus, compared with the existing parallel encryption methods [15,20,31], our proposal possesses the merit of compressibility. We set a fixed key length as 128-bit suggested by the AES. The 128-bit key K=k 0 ,k 1 ,⋯, k 127 is divided into four 32-bit sub-keys: K j sub ¼ k 32j ; k 32jþ1 ; Á Á Á ; k 32jþ31 ðj ¼ 0; 1; 2; 3Þ . Four initial values of Logistic map are derived from each sub-key ratio computed as follow:
div.formula: Φ ¼ Φ B Φ B . . . Φ B
I j ¼ K j sub P K j sub j ¼ 0; 1; 2; 3ð3Þ
F X j t À Á ¼ μX j t 1 À X j t À Á j ¼ 0; 1; 2; 3 & t ¼ 0; 1; 2; Á Á Áð4Þ
div.p: Equation (4) shows the Logistic map which is a discrete quadratic recurrence equation derived from the population growth model. This chaotic system displays a great sensitivity to initial conditions when the parameter μ takes the value between about 3.57 and 4. In order to improve the initial condition sensitivity, a pre-iteration process is carried out. Specifically, fetching values is triggered after Logistic map (4) undergoes t>t 0 rounds of iteration. Here, the constant t 0 is preset to 100 empirically. Four initial conditions are X j o ¼ I j ; j ¼ 0; 1; 2; 3 . The first element z seed directly takes the floating-point number F X 0 t 0 þ1 after the preiteration process. A Gaussian random number generator drove by z seed is intended to produce the block Gaussian random matrix Φ B . The remaining three elements, b z a ,b z b and b Z W×H , are the quantization version converted from the raw floating-point number. A decimal z j t ¼ 0:z j t ð0Þz j t ð1Þz j t ð2Þ Á Á Á is quantized according to Eq. ( 5).
div.formula: b z j t ¼ mod 100z j t ð0Þ þ 10z j t ð1Þ þ z j t ð2Þ; 2 8ð5Þ
div.p: where z j t ð0Þ stands for the decile of z j t , and the rest can be deduced by analogy. Then we have two quantized sequences:
div.formula: b z a ¼ fb z 1 t 0 þ1 ;b z 1 t 0 þ2 ; Á Á Á ;b z 1 t 0 þL g b z b ¼ fb z 2 t 0 þ1 ;b z 2 t 0 þ2 ; Á Á Á ;b z 2 t 0 þL g
div.p: The approach to generating b Z W×H is inspired by the two-dimensional Coupled Map Lattice (CML) [28]. As a spatiotemporal chaos model, the two-dimensional CML is characterized by ergodicity, sensibility and random-like behaviors. Generation procedure includes three step: lattice initialization, lattice iteration and lattice quantization. In the lattice initialization step, the chaotic sequence z 3 t 0 þ1 ; z 3 t 0 þ2 ; Á Á Á ; z 3 t 0 þW ÂH generated by Eq. ( 4) is reshaped to a matrix of size W×H. This matrix is regarded as the initial lattice, and denoted by Z O W ÂH . The lattice iteration step is represented by Eqs. ( 6) and (7).
div.formula: z n c þ1 ii;jj ¼ 1 À " ð ÞF z n c þ1 ii;jj þ 1 2 " F z n c iiþ1;jj þ F z n c ii;jjþ1 h ið6Þ
z n c þ1 ii;jj ¼ z n c þ1 ii;jj þ z n c þ1 iiþ1;jj mod 1ð7Þ
div.p: where the function F(⋅) refers to the Logistic map. The subscripts ii=1,2,⋯,H and jj=1,2, ⋯,W represent the element positions in the current lattice. Note that the periodic boundary condition z n c ii; jjþW ¼ z n c iiþH; jj ¼ z n c ii; jj is satisfied. The enumerator n c counts the rounds of iteration. Parameter ε ∊[0,1] harmonizes the weight average between two items. The operation "mod 1" restricts the value range of z n c þ1

ii; jj 2 0; 1 ½ Þ . Lattice quantization is implemented according to the same approach given in Eq. ( 5). The iteration stops when the set b Z W×H has contained L quantized lattices. The following encryption and decryption procedure makes use of this four-tuple {z seed , b z a , b z b , b Z W×H }.

div.head: Encryption procedure
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2, an original image is block-wise measured in parallel. The quantized measurement data undergo following five processes including Arnold scrambling, Mixing [31], S-box, block-wise XOR operation and communication. Let R denote the maximum round of iteration. The procedure of encryption/decryption as well as parameter setting is elaborated in the following.

[ The measurement matrix of size M×N is produced column by column using a Gaussian random number generator initialized by the seed z seed . The measurement data y p are harvested from the Eq. ( 1) block by block. The discussion about parameter M will be given later. [Step 3]: Quantization. For a given 8-bit rate, measurement data quantization is implemented through the Lloyd quantizer [17] which is known as an optimal quantizer in the mean square error sense. as illustrated in Fig. 3. In this way, the number of elements within a block becomes equal to the number of blocks, mathematically, M⋅b/B=B. Obviously, the problem how to determine the parameters M, B, b should be carefully studied. To this end, three requirements are given to handle this issue. First, M≥N/4, which is an empirical version of inequality (2) for guaranteeing the successful reconstruction [26]. Second, the square root of M, B and b must be integer. Third,
div.formula: B ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi M Á b p , which is derived from M⋅b/B=B.
div.p: Taking the typical 512×512 image as an example, we divide it into b= 64 blocks, then each block contains N=4096 data. Fixing M=1024 results in B=256. We remark that the reallocation manipulation does not violate the workload balance among multiple processors, since each block shares the same size. Therefore, challenging issues in item ( 2) and (3) become equivalent. Moreover, based on the fact that the length of measurement data M is adjustable, the workload balance property can be achieved even for non-square images. An example is shown in Fig. 4, where b=64, M=1024 and B=256. Note that, in this case, the square root of N is no longer an integer. For the sake of simplicity, in the following, we denote each block as Ŷ m,n , where m; n ¼ 1; Á Á Á ; measurement within each block as (m,n). 4 The position moving rule of (m,n) is formulated by Eq. ( 8):
div.formula: m 0 n 0 ! ¼ 1 a b ab þ 1 ! m n ! mod ffiffiffi B pð8Þ
div.p: where m; n; m 0 ; n 0 2 1; 2; Á Á Á ;
div.formula: m;n ¼ b y m;n È Sumjm; n ¼ 1; Á Á Á ; ffiffiffi B p È É .
div.p: One impressive property of this mixing operation is that a single alteration will affect the final output. Another one is M(M(Ŷ m,n ))=Ŷ m,n , which is helpful for decryption stage. [Step 7]: S-box Substitution. S-box is a basic component of block cipher, and serves as a non-linear projection through table lookup. A slight alteration causes great difference on the output side. This step provides confusion property which obscures the relationship between the key and the encrypted image. For the sake of simplicity, we employ a fixed 8×8 bits S-box suggested by AES. Let S(⋅) denote the S-box substitution manipulation. [Step 8]: Block-wise XOR. Taking the r th round as example, the output lattice is equal to the XOR between its preceding output C rÀ1 m;n and a two-dimensional quantized chaotic lattice b Z nc ffiffi ffi
div.formula: B p Â ffiffi ffi B p . C r m;n ¼ b Z n c ffiffi ffi B p Â ffiffi ffi B p È C rÀ1 m;n r ¼ 1; Á Á Á ; R where b Z n c ffiffi ffi B p Â ffiffi ffi B p 2 b Z ffiffi ffi B p Â ffiffi ffi B p ¼ b Z n c ffiffi ffi B p Â ffiffi ffi B p n c ¼ 1; 2; Á Á Á ; L j n o . Recall that b Z ffiffi ffi B p Â ffiffi ffi B p
div.p: is the forth element of the four-touple. and occupy the position (m,n), where m ′ =m and n ′ =n. Obviously, the collisionfree data exchange can be fulfilled if and only if the number of elements within a block is equal to the number of blocks. This issue has been discussed and solved in the reallocation step. In the following, we draw forth the concept of optimal diffusion [32].
Definition Suppose that each block contains B elements. After the r th round of encryption, the effect of a single bit change spreads over B r elements.

Recall that the reallocation step segments the quantized measurement image Ŷ into B blocks, and each block contains B elements. Therefore, the optimal diffusion can be fulfilled at the second round. We give concise analysis:

After the first round, the value change of an arbitrary element c m;n 2 C o m;n is propagated within the corresponding block, where 8m; n; m; n 2 1; Á Á Á ; ffiffiffi ffi B p È É . The mixing step guarantees the above internal alteration propagation mechanism. The collision-free communication unit uniformly propagates those infected elements over all blocks. Therefore, after the second round, the whole image will be infected. For a data-collision communication, more than one infected elements will co-exist in a block after the first round communication, which also indicates that some blocks lack of infected elements. Therefore, after two round encryption, the number of infected elements will be less than B 2 , and thus more round encryption is required. We conclude that optimal diffusion is equivalent to the collision-free data exchange.
Communication unit of Zhou's method [31] and Liao's method [15] exist data-collision exchange. This inefficient stage needs more than two rounds of encryption to achieve the full diffusion.

The above description is related to the encryption procedure. The operations from step 5 to step 9 should be implemented iteratively for R rounds. In the last round, the communication unit can be skipped.

div.head: Decryption procedure
div.p: The decryption procedure is composed of the inverse manipulations which are performed in reverse order. It is worth noting that the parallelism is still preserved during the decryption stage, which allows implementing the reconstruction algorithm OMP in parallel.

div.head: Security and performance evaluation
div.p: To evaluate the security and performance of an encryption algorithm, the resistance against a series of known attacks, such as brute-force attack, statistical attack and differential attack is generally investigated. In this section, security and performance evaluation includes recovery, key space, statistical analysis, sensitivity analysis, information entropy analysis and efficiency analysis. Five grayscale images with resolution 512×512 were selected as the original images as shown in Fig. 6. It should be mentioned that the proposed method is also applicable to color images by parallel encrypting each color channel.

(a) The "Lena" image, is a high-contrast image with sharp corners and textured area. (b) The "Pepper" image, contains multiple separate plain areas with various shape. The distinct edges exist in the junction between two peppers. (c) The "Baboon" image, contains a large textured area (the fur) and a homogeneous area (the face). (d) The "Testpat" image, as illustrated in Fig. 1(a), is a general test pattern. Multiple blocks with gradual grayscale surround the shrunken "Lena". (e) The "Black" image, consists of black pixels and can be regarded as an all-zero matrix.

As mentioned before, in practice, CS serves as the sampling stage. In our experiment, we simulated the CS measuring by randomly downsampling the digital image. The original image was split into b=64 blocks, and each block contained N=4096 pixels. For achieving the optimal diffusion and successful reconstruction, M=1024 was an appropriate setting. The 128-bit length original key was set to K=(0123456789ABCDEF0123456789ABC-DEF) hex . As an intuitive contrast with Fig. 1(b), we first exhibited our encrypted "Testpat" as shown in Fig. 7(d).

In the following, CS-based image encryption [11,16,23,24] and parallel image encryption [15,31] were involved as competitors for following comparative studies. We excluded the parallel method proposed in [20] from the comparison due to the absence of diffusion mechanism. The terminology "recovery" refers to decrypting and then reconstructing the plain image from its measurement data. In this sub section, assuming that the original key K was available to the recipient, we investigated the compression ratio and reconstruction quality.

Since a fixed 8-bit rate quantization was adopted, the compression ratio only relied on the parameter M. Naturally, a large M yielded the high quality reconstruction while small M leaded to an aborted case. For the original image of size 512×512, the appropriate setting M=1024 rendered the compression ratio at 0.25. For the case of non-square image as shown in Fig. 4, its corresponding compression ratio would be 0.4551.
We computed the Peak Signal Noise Ratio (PSNR) as an objective metric to evaluate the reconstruction quality. The specific calculation formulas were given as follows:
div.formula: MSE ¼ 1 bN X bN i¼1 ðx i À b x i Þ 2 PSNR ¼ 10 Â lg 255 2 MSE = À Á
div.p: where x i represented the intensity of a pixel in the original image, while its reconstruction counterpart was denoted by b x i .

In our proposal, all five PSNRs exceeded 30 dB, which indicated that the reconstruction quality was acceptable. Notably, the issue about how to improve the reconstruction quality was out of the scope of this paper. So far, there had existed too many reconstruction techniques to enumerate here. The impressive ones include orthogonal matching pursuit [26], Gradient pursuit [4], iterative shrinkage thresholding algorithm [3], FOCUSS [12] and SPARLS [1].

div.head: Key space
div.p: The 128-bit key occupied key space up to 2 128 ≈3.4028×10 38 , which could provide a sufficient security against the brute force attack for ordinary business applications. If an opponent possesses the exact knowledge about the key schedule, then they may bypass by guessing the key instead of directly guessing the 32-bit sub keys K j sub ; j ¼ 0; Á Á Á ; 3 . In that way, the opponent must exhaustively search 2 32 ⋅2 32 ⋅2 32 ⋅2 32 =2 128 possible combinations, which indicates that the opponent still have to confront an extremely heavy work.

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: To frustrate the statistical analysis attack, the encrypted image should be characterized by uniform histogram and low correlation between two adjacent pixels.

div.head: Histogram
div.p: The histogram of an encrypted image is illustrated to characterize the confusion. For exhibiting the heterogeneity, we depicted the plain and cipher histograms of three representative images, namely "Lena", "Testpat" and "Black" in Fig. 8. The second column in Fig. 8 showed that CS-based cipher values inherited the Gaussian distribution property which was introduced by the measurement matrix. In contrast, the proposed method completely dissipated the Gaussian distribution instead by a fairly uniform distribution as shown in the third column. It indicated that the proposed algorithm had a remarkable ability to resist against the statistical attack [8].

Fig. 8 Histogram test. The first column lists the histograms of original images. The second and third columns list the histograms of encrypted images obtained from the CS-based encryption methods [11,16,23,24] and the proposed method, respectively. The original test images are "Lena", "Testpat" and "Black" from top to bottom

div.head: Correlation of two adjacent pixels
div.p: To evaluate the correlation between two adjacent pixels in vertical, horizontal and diagonal directions, we carried out the following procedure. Randomly select 2,000 adjacent pixel pairs from the original image and encrypted image, respectively. Let (x i ,y i ) denote the i th pixel intensity pair. Each pair is regarded as a coordinate and placed in the rectangular coordinate system.

Intuitively, as shown in the third column of Fig. 9, the disordered distribution without the regular pattern indicated the low correlation between two adjacent pixels. We just showed the result of horizontal direction version since the distribution of vertical or diagonal direction test shared the similar modality.

Moreover, a quantitative evaluation on correlation was listed in Table 1. This quantitative evaluation demonstrated that the proposed method reduced the correlation by one order of magnitude comparing with the methods [11,16,23,24]. Equation ( 9) gave the formula for correlation calculation.
div.formula: r xy ¼ cov x; y ð Þ j j ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi DðxÞ p Â ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi DðyÞ pð9Þ
div.p: where x and y stand for the intensities of two adjacent pixels, while cov (•,•) and D(•) were computed as follows:

Fig. 9 Correlation test. The first column lists the test results of original images. The second and third columns list the test results of encrypted images obtained from the CS-based encryption methods [11,16,23,24] and the proposed method, respectively. The original test images are "Lena", "Testpat" and "Black" from top to bottom
div.formula: EðxÞ ¼ 1 N X N i¼1 x i DðxÞ ¼ 1 N X N i¼1 x i À EðxÞ ð Þ 2 cov x; y ð Þ ¼ 1 N X N i¼1 x i À EðxÞ ð Þy i À EðyÞ ð Þ
div.p: Note that we omitted to list the statistical analysis of two parallel encryption methods [15,31] because both of them could achieve the same confusion level as ours.

div.head: Sensitivity analysis
div.p: Sensitivity which is a basic criterion for an encryption method requires that a slight change results in a completely different output.

div.head: Key sensitivity
div.p: Key sensitivity is defined as the degree of the changes in the encrypted image caused by a tiny change in key [14]. Both following two tests took the "Testpat" as a plain image.

The first test verified the fact that decryption will fail even using a neighbor key. We assume that the Hamming distance between an original key and its neighbor key is one. For example, K ¼ 0123456789ABCDEF0123456789ABCDEE ð Þ hex is one of the neighbor key belonging to K. Fig. 7 (d) displayed the encrypted image by using the original key K. We then decrypted this cipher image by using the neighbor key K in turn. The noise-like reconstruction shown in Fig. 7 (b) did not leak any perceptive information, which demonstrated the failure of reconstruction when using a neighbor key.

The second test compared two encrypted images which were obtained by using key K and its neighbor key K , respectively. Fig. 7 (d) and Fig. 7 (e) depicted the corresponding two encrypted images. The difference image between these two encrypted images was shown in Fig. 7 (f) for perceptual observation. Moreover, in Table 2, we listed the percentage of different intensity when comparing two encrypted images. All the percentage values exceeded 99 %, which indicated that the tiny change in key brought great changes in the encrypted image.
The above two tests demonstrated that our proposed method was sensitive to key. All six competitors [11,15,16,23,24,31] could achieve the same key sensitivity level as ours.

div.head: Plaintext sensitivity
div.p: Plaintext sensitivity is to test the influence of changing a plaintext bit on the ciphertext [14]. This test is also known as a metric measurement of diffusion.

Since compressive sensing plays a role in sampling data, in this test, the quantized measurement image Ŷ are regarded as the "plain image". We argue that this test routine is impartial because the security strength of the second encryption stage must be not stronger than that of the entire cryptosystem.
We modified one bit of Ŷ in arbitrary position, and then iteratively performed the second stage block cipher. Two objective metrics of plaintext sensitivity, Number of Pixel Change
div.formula: i;j D i; j ð Þ M Â M Â 100%ð10Þ
UACI ¼ 1 M Â M X i;j C 1 i; j ð Þ À C 2 i; j ð Þ j j 255 " # Â 100%ð11Þ
div.p: where the symbol C 1 and C 2 denoted the encrypted images whose corresponding plain images had only one bit difference.

To conduct the comparative study, three encryption methods including Zhou's method [31], Liao's method [15] and our proposal were applied on five test images, respectively. We excluded the CS-based image encryption methods [11,16,23,24] from the comparison due to the absence of diffusion mechanism.

A satisfactory diffusion property required that NPCR and UACI were close to 0.9961 and 0.3346, respectively [30]. Table 3 counted and listed the average NPCP and UACI round by round. Our proposal achieved the optimal diffusion, and outperformed both Zhou's method [31] and Liao's method [15].

div.head: Ciphertext sensitivity
div.p: Ciphertext sensitivity is a measurement to authenticate the data integrity and generally expected from cryptographic techniques [19].

Ciphertext sensitivity was evaluated by the same measurement NPCR and UACI as listed in Table 4. It should be noted that the optimal value of UACI became close to 0.25 due to the Gaussian distribution property of the quantized measurements.

div.head: Avalanche criterion
div.p: The avalanche criterion is known as a test about the change rate, which measures the percentage of the changed bits in the encrypted image when one bit alteration occurs in the original image. In the ideal case, the change rate should be exactly equal to 50 %. The results listed in Table 5 showed that the change rate achieved by our method was extremely close to the ideal case and comparable with the existing methods [15,31].

div.head: Information entropy analysis
div.p: Information entropy can be used to characterize the confusion, and is calculated by H(C)=∑ P(C i, j )log 2 (1/C i, j ). For a grayscale image, if 2 8 =256 intensities appear with equal probability, the entropy H(C) reaches the maximum value 8. We calculated the entropy of encrypted images in the first two rounds. From the observation of Table 6, our method could achieve outstanding confusion, and outperformed the CS-based methods [11,16,23,24], in the sense that the corresponding entropy H(C) was more close to the maximum value 8. Since both Zhou's method [31] and Liao's method [15] could achieve the same confusion level as ours, we omitted their quantitative results.

div.head: Efficiency analysis
div.p: The proposed method enhanced the security of the CS-based works [11,16,23,24] in a relatively high-efficiency mode. Four mainly contributing factors are:

(1) Compressive sensing directly captures a compressed signal representation without going through the intermediate stage of acquiring Nyquist rate samples. (2) The round iteration is implemented on the quantized measurement data in its dimension reduction space. (3) Parallel structure allows encrypting/decrypting multiple blocks simultaneously. (4) Optimal diffusion achievement. After only two rounds of encryption, the full diffusion can be achieved.

Table 7 compared the encryption time between our proposed method and the parallel image encryption methods [15,31]. For each encryption method, the encryption was implemented iteratively until the full diffusion property has been achieved. In addition, the time counter was triggered from the image sampling stage. All experiments were performed using MATLAB R2010b on a personal computer with a 1.8 GHZ Athlon Dual-Core Processor, 2 GB memory and 120 GB harddisk capacity.
The encryption time results in Table 7 indicated that the proposed method outperformed both Zhou's method [31] and Liao's method [15] with respect to the encryption speed.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, we investigated the weakness of existing CS-based encryption methods from the perspective of the chosen-plaintext attack. A parallel image encryption method was proposed under the compressive sampling circumstance to enhance the security and performance. The proposed block cipher structure consisted of scrambling, mixing, S-box and block-wise XOR with chaotic lattice. Both collision-free data exchange and optimal diffusion were achieved owing to a well designed reallocation and communication unit. We evaluated the security, and conducted performance comparative studies through the experiment. The results demonstrated that our method had the ability of resistance against the chosen-plaintext attack and outperformed the existing parallel image encryption with respect to the compressibility and the encryption speed.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 1 Encryption performance of applying the AES on a grayscale image. a the original image. b the corresponding encrypted image

Key schedule and chaotic model In this sub-section, we describe the key schedule and chaotic model for the generation of seed and XOR initial state. A four-tuple z seed ;b z a ;b z b ; b Z W ÂH n o is collected for future operation. The first element z seed is a floating-point initial number used for generating the block Gaussian random matrix Φ B . Both the second and third elements are one-dimensional quantized vectors. They are regarded as parameters to activate the permutation operation. Their length L depends on the product between the maximum encryption round and the number of blocks. The last element b Z W×H represents a set of two-dimensional chaotic lattices serving as initial state for block-wise XOR. The number of lattices in set bZ W×H is equal to the same length L, while dimension W×H is determined by the block size. Following procedures describe the four-tuple generation approach.

note.p: Liao et al.[15] claimed that the full diffusion could be achieved even after the first round of encryption. However, their experiment in diffusion performance evaluation was not impartial. If one changes the original image pixel in the second quadrant, at least three rounds of encryption were necessary. Therefore, the property that full diffusion could be achieved after the first round encryption was just a best case. It should be bear in mind that when evaluating the security, only the worst boundary can be taken as a result.
The necessary round is defined as the minimum round to achieve the full confusion and diffusion.
Definition of unit throughput. Assume that the workload allocated to a processor is w, and the processing capacity of this processor is c. The unit throughput is defined as w/c.
Here, (m,n) is the coordinate of a quantized measurement within a block, while coordinate printed in the bold font (m,n) stands for the position of a block.
